Reviews.Title: Compare FIRE HD to the KINDLE FIRE GEN 2
Reviews.Author: clickz4 "clickz4"

logTag.type = "text/javascript"; logTag.src = "/gp/customer-media/du/log.html?ie=UTF8&p=CustomerImage&s=CustomerVideoPlay"; head[0].appendChild(logTag); } if (cv_mo1ZPFGB73SL6K0currentClick) { return cv_mo1ZPFGB73SL6K0currentClick(); } } } Length:: 2:29 MinsUPDATE: I bought both a Fire HD and a Gen 2. (as a present to my mother in law) My initial reviews were written after playing with them for like 20 minutes. I merged both reviews into one to really compare the two products. I'm still answering questions in the comments if you have any. And see the video that compares the two and gives a mini tour of the Kindle system.My Background: I've had 4 android phones, I've had multiple e-readers and my latest 'touch' device is the Le Pan II Android tablet. I've worked on several iPads but never been compelled to spend the extra money for one myself. Wife has a first generation Fire.============The new Kindle Fire and Fire HD are the second generation color kindle e-reader/media player/tablet devices. The original Fire received a lot of well earned 4 star reviews. It was a great product but at the end of the day, it was a first generation product. It was no iPad slayer. The Fire HD raises the bar and raises it quite a lot. Jeff Bezos said they set out to make the best tablet available period and -in some regards- they did that in spades. In other ways not so much. (more on this below in the closing thoughts)HARDWARE:BUILD QUALITY:- BOTH are top Notch. I didn't expect anything less from Amazon but they really are solid feeling.- FIRE HD lighter and while it is about the same thickness, the edges are rounded more like an iPad. sleeker look and more comfortable to hold.- FIRE GEN 2 is heavier and 'boxier' built to more fit existing covers I guess. It's heavier too.SIZING:The HD is just a bit taller but a decent bit wider than the Fire. --- NOTE pay attention to accessories because THEY ARE NOT THE SAME SIZE. The cover from my wife's Gen 1 Kindle will fit the Gen 2 kindle (sorta) but NOT THE HD.THE SCREEN:- FIRE HD SUMMED UP IN TWO WORDS Oh. My. The Le Pan, the iPads and the Gen 2 Fire all have great screens. The Fire HD takes them all out. I read somewhere there was polarizing a filter over the Fire HD screen. Polarizers reduce glare by only letting 'straight' light though not off angle bounced light. This makes an enormous difference to this display. The off angle viewing is probably the best I have seen in any flat screen. 6 stars.- FIRE GEN 2 Still a high quality screen. I'd same the same or better than any other high end tablet on the market.- NOTE A few people in the comments asked about the touch response. - I do not have a problem except in the browser, it is sorta too sensitive. If you move your finger smoothly you can avoid the jitters.THE WIFI.- FIRE HD I admit only the geeky probably care but the wifi rocks. I have a mimo router and one quick copy from my server and I was getting almost 30MB/s. To put that into perspective, that's about as fast and an external USB Hard drive can push data to your computer. (USB 3.0 will be faster but they are rare today) -- The other thing is that I have a long skinny house and when I'm in the back bath, the Le Pan drops off. (ahem not that I surf on the potty or anything, just when I test it, you know.) With the Fire HD I can surf in the back yard.- FIRE GEN 2 still got 20MB/sec. But consider this... at that speed you can fill the entire memory in 5 minutes. Seems good enough to me.THE SOUND:- FIRE HD ok I'm a bit of an audio snob. The sound is fantastic for being a tablet. Which is to say it's still only marginally acceptable. You can still buy a $15 pair of Koss KSC75 headphones and blow the speakers away BUT I will say this is the first device I would actually listen to music on. The rest I simply don't even bother. I suspect most people would call the sound excellent.- FIRE GEN 2 still have a very good sound. For the spoken word it would be very fine. For music it is lacking in my book.SPEED: Both are quick with the HD being quicker. The Le Pan II is no slouch but I think the HD edges it out. Since the Le Pan apparent died this morning it's hard to compare. :-(NOTE: IT DOES NOT COME WITH A WALL WORT CHARGER It comes with a micro USB cable that can be used with your existing USB wall worts. (ie your cell phone charger) You can buy a rapid charger for it or even plug it into your computer to charge. This is an odd choice from Amazon IMO.NOTE 2: Unlike the Gen 1 Fire, (and contrary to what you might have read) the new Kindles DO NOT support flash. Rumor has it you can hack it to install Flash I have not tried yet. I'll try to run this down by this weekend.NEW FEATURES (as promised)EXCHANGE CALENDAR SYNC:BOTH - Exchange on the Fire (both) just rocks. I really like the calendar app. The contact manager can't keep up with the one on the iPad but it is sufficient. Ditto the email. But the setup was easy and it seemed fast. Love it.SKYPE:- FIRE HD Spent way too long video skyping today. It worked as well as skype ever works. (long time skype users will understand that) yes it was glitchy but less than other platforms so no complaints. The sound really made a difference here.- Fire GEN 2 I don't think Skype came with it. I'll update with a definitive later.HDMI- FIRE HD ONLY I promised someone in the comments to test this soon but I misplaced my HDMI cable. (drat) I guess I'll order a new one and update when it arrives.BLUETOOTH- FIRE HD ONLY worked very smoothly pairing with LG tone. (great product btw) I'll be using that for Skype in the future.FREETIME: BOTH This is a widely requested feature that allows multiple users (i.e. kids) to log in and have their own customized tablet experience. It also allows parents to limit the time kids spend on certain tasks, like watching movies, while giving them unlimited time to read. Parents have been asking for this forever. (Are you listening Apple?) I wasted 20 minutes looking for it before I looked it up and Amazon is not shipping it until next month. The existing parental controls are pretty decent actually.CLOSING THOUGHTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS:If you're new to Kindle make sure you understand what you are buying here. Kindles are made -and sold at a highly discounted price- to allow you to purchase media from Amazon. Don't think of this as an android tablet, because it really isn't. Yes Amazon uses the Android operating system but you'd never know they hide it so well. This device is made (basically) exclusively to read/watch/listen to media you buy from Amazon. In that regard this device is about as great as they could make it. HOWEVER. The Kindle Fire (first generation) was notorious for not playing well with many Android apps. If you're a app monster or looking for something to replace your laptop to allow you do work on the road and occasionally consume media, you need to look at an Android tablet or an iPad. But don't let that discourage you:Via Amazon Prime, you get 25,000 streaming movies and T.V. shows you can watch 24/7 unlimited. We dropped Netflix because Prime Instant Video was so good. Amazon gives you a free month with the either Fire so you'll get to see the value before you buy. (it's a no brainer btw) There are also over a million free books available for the Kindle. I try to limit how many I buy/download but I have over 100 books on my previous Kindle that are waiting to be read, all but like 4 of them were free. Also if you own a Kindle and subscribe to Prime, you can borrow one book per month from the Paid section. And big name books too... all 7 Harry Potter books are up there. If you figure that is worth at least 10 bucks a month, you're getting $120 of content per year and Prime only costs (I think) $79. Or looked at another way, that's $240 in content in two years and the Fire HD is only $199.If you're new to e-readers, owning one might just change your life. I had probably read 8 book length books in the last decade. (I'm a periodical junkie.) I now read at least one book per week. I was a big reader before but I'm reading more than I ever have in my life. Many studies show that people are reading as much as 3X more when they get an e-reader. If you're a parent looking to inspire a love of reading in a child, STOP. DO NOT PASS GO, DO NOT COLLECT $200. Buy them an e-reader.SO THE BIG QUESTION, WHICH ONE DO I BUY?- If you're on a VERY tight budget the Fire Gen 2 is a great product at a great price point. Coupled with Prime, you have access to mountains of cheap content.HOWEVER. When you look at what you get for the small difference in cost, the Fire HD blows it away... You get a better screen, better sound, bluetooth, it's faster, thinner and lighter than the Fire. You also get double the memory, better wifi and over 2 hours more battery life. All for $40. I guess Amazon wants to make color Kindles as affordable as possible but I don't even know why they made the small one. I'm not sorry I bought it but all things considered, I would buy two big ones if I had it to do over.I'll be taking questions in the comments for the next week or maybe more, so feel free to ask.Hope this was helpful.

Reviews.Title: Wonderful product and incredible support from Amazon!
Reviews.Author: Lisa
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Kindle Fire ten months ago for my daughter.  Three weeks after she got it, it was stolen.  Amazon worked with our police department to find the person who had taken it.  Amazon first put a hold on the person's account and shut down the Kindle Fire so it wouldn't work.  Then, once Amazon had a subpoena, Amazon gave the police all the information the thief had registered to my daughter's Kindle Fire and the police were able to recover it and get it back to us.  Since that time, we have purchased an additional Kindle Fire and, just recently, a Kindle Fire HD.  We use them like iPads at a fraction of the cost and the number of free books and apps available is unmatched by their competitors.  Our oldest Kindle Fire (ten months old) just stopped charging and I contacted Amazon via Live Chat.  Immediately, they said they would send me a replacement Kindle Fire and would also email me a printing label for free shipping to return the defective one.  Their customer service is incredible!  The Kindle Fire itself is amazing.  The internet is fast; connects perfectly to all wi-fi; the graphics are clear and sharp; the books and apps offered are endless.  My teenager listens to Pandora on it constantly.  I'm always reading.  My husband checks the sports scores.  My young sons are always playing the game apps. We have them protected in KlearKase protectors and have found them to be well-made, quality devices. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend a Kindle Fire to anyone of my friends and family.

Reviews.Title: Best value
Reviews.Author: Me "Me"
Reviews.Content: I just received my kindle fire today.  I had a hard time deciding between the HD, this, and the paperwhite.  I decided on this one, because I really thought I'd like the immersion reading.  I have an audible account and I've been reading along to the audiobooks.  It's amazing how fast I can get through the books (at 3x speed) and I really retain the info.  The immersion reading is super-easy to use and definitely worth upgrading to this.  The whole point of the kindle is to read more, and this new feature makes it possible to read 2 or 3 times as many books in the same amount of time.  I'm an average-speed reader and was able to read 4 books (with the help of the audiobook reading pace)  in the last 30 days and one was the 800+ page Stephen king, "11/22/63".I also tested out the text to speech.  It's a lady's voice and much, much, easier to understand than the text to speech on my kindle keyboard.  It also has many speed options and I think it reads faster than my kindle keyboard version.  I am very, very pleased with it.It is much more responsive than the previous kindle fire I'm upgrading from.If you are worried about the free offers, don't be.  I DETEST commercials and advertising so much, I quit reading magazines and watching television.  The offers only show on the startup, no big deal.  I already took advantage of a $5.00 credit for amazon video.  I was able to rent two movies and it only cost me 89 cents, when it was said and done, and I was planning on renting Hunger Games tonight, anyway.  So, so far, I don't mind the offers at all.My favorite feature is the immersion reading and the text-to-speech improvements.  I also downloaded all the free kindle books with the free audiobooks for the immersion experience.  These are books I always wanted to read,but never had the discipline to just read them.  Reading and listening to those books are worth the price of this new gadget, IMO.Way to go, Amazon, for a great product and a great price!P.S.I have an iPad, and the last time I went on vacation, I left it at home and brought only my fire and kindle keyboard.  I didn't miss my iPad at all and this new gen fire is even better.  Seriously, it's that good.

Reviews.Title: Great product but they get you with the ads and missing accessories
Reviews.Author: Old School Working Mom "Old School"
Reviews.Content: My 7 year old son has the 1st gen Kindle Fire, and we've been very happy with it.  He mostly plays games on it now, but we plan to purchase more movies and books for it in the future.  My 5 year old wanted one too, so we just purchased the 2nd gen Kindle Fire for her.  She had been saving her allowance and birthday money this whole year for it.  We purchased one the day they were announced!We've had it now for 3 days... and while it's still the same great product, we were disappointed to find (after receiving the device) that the 2nd generation Fire comes WITHOUT a wall charger (which the first gen Fire had) and has a whole mess of ads loaded onto it. My 5 year old can't read very well yet - she couldn't figure out how to get rid of the ads, and was constantly yelling for me to come help her.  Also, some of the ads featured more mature themes (ads for sexy prime time tv shows, for example) that I would not want to expose my young child to.To purchase the wall charger, it cost us an extra $20, and it cost us $15 to have the ads turned off.  So now we're up to $194 for the Kindle Fire that we thought we were getting for $159, plus a whole bunch of time wasted trying to figure out how to turn off the ads, and waiting for the wall charger to arrive.I am normally a HUGE Amazon fan, but this one leaves a bad taste in my mouth.  Would have given the device 4-5 stars on its own, but with the extra expenses and hassle, I have to take it down a couple stars.***Update Oct 10, 2012***  Interesting that many folks have taken my review as an opportunity to comment on my parenting skills.  While I'm sure folks are "well intentioned" (sarcasm), I don't recall asking for parenting advice. Many have said it's ridiculous to buy an eReader for a child who can't read. Yet the FIRE is marketed as a competitor to a tablet device, not an eReader.  The Fire does everything the iPad can do (except take pictures and videos). My children prefer to read books on paper. Instead, they use the Fire almost exclusively as a gaming device as there are hundreds of free (or super cheap) game apps for kids - including educational apps.  They also listen to music and watch videos on it. I looked at it as a replacement for my daughter's leapster (which she is aging out of) and as an alternative to a portable DVD player and/or iPod.  Several devices in one.  As we are getting ready to take the kids on a cross-country trip, I will be thrilled not to have to lug around several devices that come with DVDs and expensive game cartridges that are easily lost. We will pack one device. Done.***Update Oct 22, 2012*** Sorry, me again.  First, wanted to THANK those who offered support and told me to ignore the negative nellies who suggested I was an indulgent parent raising the spoiled rotten brats of the future. Secondly, wanted to respond to some questions I've repeatedly received.  The ads appear primarily on the lock screen.  When unlocked, they disappear.  For adult users who are used to dealing with ads in free apps, this might be something you'd be willing to contend with to save a few bucks.  But this was a confusing concept for my 5 year old - and I repeat that the ads I saw were too mature for a young audience.  Even after I paid the $15 to have the ads removed, my daughter's Kindle still received an ad to "Vote for Obama". It appears as a banner at the top of every screen and I have not been able to get rid of it.  I am extremely irritated with this, as it seems some ads will get thru regardless.Others have commented that it's cheap to buy a wall charger, and to quit complaining about it.  OK, I see your point - but if it's so cheap, then Amazon should provide it.  I find it absolutely unacceptable that Amazon would not provide a wall charger.  I realize Amazon loses money on the device, but they do so anticipating they will more than make up for that loss in profit from the apps, books, and movie purchases.  As far as I can tell, Amazon doesn't seem to be hurting.  So come on, Amazon, throw in the darned wall charger already!!Finally, since I purchased this item on Day One of its release, I see that Amazon has updated its product description so it's more obvious as to what the device does - and doesn't - come with. Additionally, the product title now includes the words "with special offers" (IMHO, a deceptive way of saying it comes loaded up with ads) - But I'm glad Amazon added it - now people can be more informed than I was about what they are getting themselves into.I'm an Amazon Prime member - so have invested pretty heavily in Amazon.  If I weren't a Prime member, I would have considered other brands over Amazon's Kindle.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Value for the Price and Improvements Over First Generation Fire
Reviews.Author: Michael Gallagher
Reviews.Content: To sum up what I will tell you about in the details below, for just $159 you are getting one heck of a deal on a tablet computer - especially if you compare it to the $199 for the first-generation Fire this one is replacing and the $500 or more you can spend on a Wi-Fi version of the iPad.  Overall, if you consider the price and the functionality I think this is an outstanding tool / toy.  My review below compares a lot of the features of this version of the Fire to the original Fire, but also some of the features for a first-time user.Wi-Fi Connectivity:My standard test for trying out new gadgets is to see how fast they run side-by-side with a known piece of equipment doing the same test at the best place of Wi-Fi in my house and the worst place where it drags.  In this comparison, I had this version of the Fire sitting next to the previous version of the Fire, my Motorola RAZR smartphone, my iPad 2 (yes, the Kindle guy uses an iPad for work), and the new 7" Fire HD (the Fire HD is in a separate yet similar review) all just using a Wi-Fi connection vs. cellular connectivity..My website test is to hit the mobile websites of FoxNews, CNN, my personalized Yahoo page, Google, and the Houston Chronicle.  The ones that were usually slow on the other devices and were slow on the Kindle Fire (Houston Chronicle and CNN), and for the other sites I couldn't tell a difference in speed at the location closest to my router.  When I went to the slowest / worst reception location of my house, the speed did not have a noticeable difference in the other devices, except it did lose connection on CNN.  Basic web searches on Google were all at the same speed.Screen Display / Video Playback:Amazon has made a few tweaks in the display / resolution, and I compared the viewing experience watching - don't laugh - the first episode of the Wonder Woman TV series from the 70's.  The display on this Fire was one heck of a lot better in terms of sharpnessthan last year's model.  For you technical folks out there, the display is the same 1024x600 on last year's model yet looked crisper - the only thing I can attribute that to is last year's model I have has been used quite a bit and maybe there is some decrease in the view over time or it could be because I have a 3M screen protector on the old and haven't put one on yet with the new.  I don't know, it's just better looking.Sound / Music Playback:Similar to last year's model, the two speakers are located at the top of the Kindle Fire in two not-noticeable ports.  My test of this feature was cranking up Van Halen's Panama to maximum volume (I wanted to see if it could really play the guitar licks), and I would alternate covering one speaker up over the other: you have true stereo sound with no degradation of the sound that makes you think you are about to blow the speaker.  The headphone jack is located at the bottom of the unit just to the left of the power switch and the micro-USB port.  I don't like the placement here, as I tend to read books in the portrait mode (up / down similar to holding a book) vs. landscape mode, and the bottom of my headphone cord tends to "poke" you in the leg while reading and listening to a song at the same time.Email Setup:Email setup was very easy, but I will tell you I am using an existing app called Enhanced Email that I received here on the Amazon app store for free vs. what came as standard with the Fire.  I did setup the email app that came with the program with no problem - it took about a minute to setup my main Google account - and I was able to send and receive emails with no problem.  For those of you asking yourself why am I using the Enhanced Email program, the simple answer is like many of you I have more than one email account: you can quickly switch back and forth on the accounts with the tool.  The lazy person in me appreciates that as I don't like getting out of the lazy chair once I'm settled in!New Tabs and Screen Layout:In addition to the normal Newsstand, Books, Music, Video, Docs, Apps, and Web tabs Amazon has added a new look and feel to the overall display such as rather than 5 rows of 5 apps per row on the apps tab it is now 4 rows of apps with 4 apps per row which means bigger icons and fonts (yes), but more things to scroll through to find what you are looking for.  To offset that pain, I think that's why the added the new tabs called Shop, Games, Audiobooks, and Offers.  While many of these are self-explanatory, there are a LOT of ads in each of the tabs - after all, Amazon wants you to buy a lot of stuff to help offset whatever the true cost of this unit is.While the apps tab has all of your apps in the cloud or on the device, the games tab basically slices and dices the apps you have to be game specific - that's pretty handy and helps out quite a bit, especially if you have a lot of apps and want to sit down and play a game (although you still have to scroll away to find, say, a business app in the app tab).What I think is a really nice new feature is the Audiobooks tab.  Amazon of course gives you many opportunities in this tab to make purchases from their Audible subsidiary, but you also have a "Library" area where you can see your audiobooks that are stored either on the Cloud or on your Kindle Fire in the Device tab.Reading Books:When the Fire first came out, I preferred reading on my e-Ink Kindle and not at all on the Fire.  That's because I think reading is easier on my eyes with the e-Ink version of Kindle, but I'm getting there!  Turning pages is pretty darn easy - just tap the side of the screen to go to the next page or back a page, or you can swipe your finger across the screen to do the same.Feature I wish this had?The #1 thing would have to be a Bluetooth connectivity option.  Of course, if I put this right next to my iPad there could be others such as the larger screen and a 3G or 4G connection option, but that's going to be in next month's release and I would call myself an iPad-lite user vs. an experienced pro so who knows what else I could be missing (life has been good so far, so I'm not complaining)?  For $159, I feel like I am getting a lot already.The #2 thing would be a plug / charger that connects to an electrical outlet vs. a USb port on your computer or a USB-compatible charging plug you may already own.  I realize they had to cut things out to keep the cost down to $159, and luckily I - like many of you - have lots of these things laying around.  First time buyers may not, but they might be in the minority.Overall, at $159 this is not a great deal it is an outstanding deal.  Kids will love it as they can read books, play games, watch TV and movies, and a whole lot of other things.  Adults should like it for the exact same reasons, but while I try to minimize the amount of work-related stuff I do at home with the business apps that are available here in the Amazon App store and other places around the Internet I can also work on Excel and Word-compatible files when I have to without having to fire up my work laptop or whatever the case may be.

Reviews.Title: The Charging Port Let Down DUN DUN DUNNNNNN!!!!!!!!
Reviews.Author: hair8girl
Reviews.Content: First I have to say that I feel sorry for the customer service people that work ay Amazon and that all of them have been nice even with the fact their hands were tied. I got my first Kindle Fire in Feb of this year 2012. For many months I enjoyed it with no problems. Then the charging port became loose and would no longer charge. Called Amazon I was sent a brand new Kindle Fire. Sweet!! I did notice the port was loose right away but figured hey maybe this was the "fix" to the problem. Two months later same thing. Sent a new Kindle Fire. A month after that same thing. Now another month later same thing working on my fourth. After all this I requested an "up grade" to which I was told policy would not allow it. Now I feel angry and DO NOT EVEN FIND NEW KINDLE FIRE HD APPEALING. I am scared to buy any Kindle Fire product after this. Super sad too due to the fact I may have to find a new tablet company. I loved my Kindle Fire but now I do not even want to open the box with my fourth replacement Kindle Fire just to be let down.

Reviews.Title: Extremely Disappointing
Reviews.Author: Margaret Kohut "Vienna"
Reviews.Content: I am on my 9th Kindle Fire and I've had enough with replacements of replacements of replacements.....you get the idea. When the Fire works properly, it absolutely ROCKS. No other machine comes close IMO. The problem has always been defective the battery charging port; it becomes loose (even when handled with kid gloves) after a short time of use and won't charge properly. With Fire replacement #9, the battery itself died after only days of use and will not charge. I'm done. No more replacements of this junk. CAVEAT BEWARE!The good thing is Amazon's (usually) excellent customer service. The phone reps were always courteous and tried to be helpful; THIS ISN'T THEIR FAULT. So here's the deal I was offered: I can get replacement #10, or I can upgrade to the new Fire HD with 80% credit. Since I'm not a complete idiot, I took the HD deal. It's supposedly a different machine in construction. I love the Fire --- when it works ---so I'll give this a try. If I have problems with it, I'm headed to the iPad; more expensive, less bull@!&* so I figure I'll break even.I have a Kindle DX that has always worked perfectly and I'd kill and eat anyone who tried to steal it. But the first generation Fire has problems; I can see that it isn't getting very good reviews. I really hope the HD is better.BOTTOM LINE: Skip the "plain" Fire and go directly to the HD. After nine of them, I'd trust me if I were you!

Reviews.Title: Poor product support
Reviews.Author: Buckshot
Reviews.Content: I've enjoyed my Kindle Fire for the past 6 months. Turned it on this morning and there's a large grey stripe right across the middle of the screen. Called customer service. The rep very politely told me that I could get a replacement for $100.00. She was unable to get my Kindle repaired under the "1 Year Warranty"? Very disapointed with the lack of product support. My Kindle is always in a hard sided case. I'm the only one that uses it. It has never been abused. Needless to say, I will not be replacing it with another Kindle. I'll put my $$ toward something from a company willing to stand behind their product.Kindle Fire, Full Color 7" Multi-touch Display, Wi-Fi

Reviews.Title: perfect size and great picture
Reviews.Author: kindlequeen
Reviews.Content: I purchased this product for my husband and he loves it! The price point of 159 was a no brainer and with all the apps and features on a device larger than a cell, but not as bulky as a laptop or even a ipad. Great!

Reviews.Title: Really wanted to love it, but could barely like it...
Reviews.Author: mandaleah
Reviews.Content: Got my Kindle Fire about a month ago for going back to school. Right out of the box I loved it. Got it a pretty case and screen protector and immediately stuck it in there before ever even powering it on.Right out of the box it had issues. The touch screen would sometimes not recognize my touch. I'd have to turn the screen on and off again several times to even unlock the dumb thing. I had read about it, and I never thought it could have been THAT bad.. but it was.But I kept it.. and read some books. Started some really fun games and paid real money for things device specific (regrettably so). I dealt with the issues in sensitivity, it wasn't a deal breaker for me.But what really took the cake was when I took it to the doctor with me. Two different appointments two days in a row. Fully charged it the night before, sat it in my bag, and then off to the doctor I went. 20 minutes after sitting it in my bag, I pull it out.. and it's off. Now that's strange, I thought, the battery was FULLY CHARGED and the stupid thing WOULD NOT POWER ON. AT ALL. I spent the 45 minute wait trying to figure out what had happened. Popped it out of it's little case, looked all over.. felt it to see if maybe it had overheated? No way.. After 45 minutes of continuously pressing the on/off button it finally turned back on. With close to a full battery I was flabbergasted.. Why did it turn off? Why would it not turn back on? I thought it was a fluke... The next day it happened again.And it's happened about a dozen times since then in less than two weeks. Well today was the last straw for me. It completely froze up on me and randomly turned off as I was playing a game. It had never actually shut off in front of me, but there is obviously something defective with my device.Also had problems with the charging port like lots of other people have mentioned. Have to plug and unplug it a dozen or so times to get it to register, and even then sometimes will not charge.Will be dropping it off at UPS tomorrow. No thanks Amazon, no thanks. I am not paying that kind of money on a student budget for something I feel like is going to stop working any minute now. I'll stick to good ol' ink and paper.

Reviews.Title: amazon will give you a $10 promotion certificate if you didnT order a charger
Reviews.Author: Carrie Sheridan "carrie sheridan"
Reviews.Content: i ordered the 2nd gen kindle fire 7" and 7" HD plus the square trade warranty and leather cover but unchecked the box for the $9.99 power charge. when my kindle fires arrived and i saw there was just a usb cord, i expected that amazon would help me get the charger needed for the $9.99 it would have cost if i had bought it as part of the package. they did gladly and quickly... so everyone, just go on to help and live chat and you'll get a $10 "promotion certificate." new buyers, you MUST buy the $9.99 power charger WITH the kindle fire.i must agree with other reviewers that i was dismayed to see all the screens of ads...and i hope amazon decides to stop that.the amazing thing to me - especially for kids learning to read is being able to go to the Aa setting and set "text-to-speech" and have the book read to you! anyone can learn to read by themselves, look up definitions of words they don't know. the barbara bush literacy foundation should be promoting this like crazy!also the "immersion reading" of being able to synch up the text with an audible.com recording is probably incredible. again, especially for kids learning to read.i like the feel of the $159 model better than the $199 model which feels like a mini ipad more than like a kindle.but these are all great, shockingly a good value to read free downloadable classics and childrens classic literature,to listen to a book being read to you...to access Khan Academy math and science tutorials.also check out  the jigzone website... a free jigsaw puzzle site with 100s of pictures and a choice of 6-247 pieces in different cuts: classic,tetris, polygons, euros,the 48 states... with 100s of free books downloadable, being able to fall asleep with someone reading to you (tired parents AND kids) and being able to do puzzles,play scrabble on [...]..a kindle fire costs just $1 per fun thing to do! amazing.

Reviews.Title: Why only 3 satrs?
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I don't like negative hardware reviews that address service/value issues instead of the hardware.  The review typically should be confined to the functioning of the hardware.That said, as a household that currently has 9 active Kindles, and have purchased well over 20 (gifts, etc), I feel compelled to make a short comment about the pricing model on the new Kindle Fire.The original Fire was $199.00, had no ads, and included a wall charger.The new improved Fire $159.00 (yes it is better), includes advertisements but no wall charger.  Remove the ads?  $15.00.  Purchase the wall charger?  $19.99.  Real cost of the Fire compared to the old one?  193.99. So the new Fire is actually only $6.01 cheaper than the original version.And yes, I see the subsidized price of the charger now after the fact (unfortunately customer service, both in chat and on the phone offered me nothing).I'm a fan of Amazon, we've been Prime members for 7 years.  Unfortunately I find the pricing to be disingenuous on the new models.The Fire itself is at least a 4 star rating however.

Reviews.Title: love it.
Reviews.Author: Kennerg
Reviews.Content: I have had my Kindle Fire since about a month after it was launched. I use it every day.My wife has a Nook Color that she bought about 9 months prior. She upgraded from a black & white Nook and had given me the old Nook. I liked it but was having trouble seeing the screendue to lighting and glare.We went to Target where they sold both the Kindle Fire and Nook Colorado at that time. I thought that the Kindle was a more open platform than the Nook, so I bought it.We have wifi at home so the Kindle is great for checking movie listings, email, weather, news and social media. I can play games (stupid zombies or suduko or solitaire) or read a book. To be honest, I don't really know how to operate my wife's Nook but she can do everything on the Nook that I can on the Kindle.The major difference I can see is that Kindle does not list page numbers like a book, it just lists a percentage of the book complete. The other difference is that Amazon has a lot more free books than Barnes & Nobel.

Reviews.Title: Poor product
Reviews.Author: Rebecca
Reviews.Content: The Kindle Fire did not work with a program that the company promised it would, then it began malfunctioning.  It would turn itself on for no reason, when turned on it would not open and then recycle to the logo page and not allow me to shut it off.  It would continue this for 20-30 minutes and the battery would get hot enough to be uncomfortable to hold.  I returned the product and refused a replacement since the company wanted me to charge me for the replacement.

Reviews.Title: It would be good if I could download from the cloud!!
Reviews.Author: Victoria McNamara "Victoria McNamara"
Reviews.Content: So I bought my mother a kindle fire 2 after she had her 1st generation kindle fire for a year.  She wanted the text-to-speech and I thought that this would be perfect for her...well it would if the books would download from the cloud!! After several calls to customer service - all of the reps were extremely nice and after replacing the kindle 3 times we're still having the exact same problem.  When in the cloud for books it gives an error of "Launch taking longer wait or close" Of course, we wait and after 5-10 minutes the books will pop up and this is every time we switch to the books tab.  So we call again and the rep say well you have too many books and you need to DELETE some!!? What? This is an EReader!! It's for reading - you don't delete books! This would be like throwing out your library! So now we're stuck with a 2nd generation kindle fire that takes forever to load and when it does you can download a book but then when you go back it takes another 10 minutes to load the cloud but hey we have text-to-speech!!! So that gets 2 stars alone. Otherwise until they start listening to their customers about what we want, I may not buy another Kindle from them.  Not because they haven't been accommodating because they have...but because in their rush for technology - it has totally screwed up a potentially awesome product because of it. Because of this cloud issue I may have to return this item because I don't want to have to wait for 10 minutes or 20 minutes to see what's in my library.  Which is a real shame...UPDATE*****10/22/12*****AWESOME CUSTOMER SERVICE!!!So I post my review and low and behold a customer service rep calls me and wants to talk about the problem that I'm having.  He was very nice and concerned about the issue.  He gave me an alternative by going to manage my kindle and looking at books there however, I did that this weekend and it was a lot of work.  So I'm actually very impressed that I got called and even though that didn't work and it still takes forever for the cloud to load, I'm impressed by the customer service on the product itself. So even though the product might be a little lackluster the customer service isn't!!!

Reviews.Title: New Kindle is Kool
Reviews.Author: Dlc
Reviews.Content: I have the last kindle fire and thought it was good but this new kindle fire is great. I like the look and feel it's much faster and was set up when I recieved it out of box impressive. The screen is very clear and the Icons are set up better than the last. This is the only tablet I think necessary. I own an Ipad and its nowhere near as user friendly and its too bulky, I like that I can see videos without worry. Great buy. Would do it all over again, and the packaging was too cool and cute.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Review
Reviews.Author: Theresa
Reviews.Content: I have been through 3 kindle fires since this time last year. Every time I finally was able to put all of my apps and photos on my NEW kindle I was having trouble with it and replacing it AGAIN. Amazon however, was very good about replacing them, but after kindle number 3 I was just done.

Reviews.Title: Perfect
Reviews.Author: travis
Reviews.Content: Perfect size.Perfect price.Perfect performance.This device is PERFECT for kids or someone who just wants read books and browse the Internet! I sold a first generation Ipad and bought two of these...they outperformed the iPad WHO KNEW?!!

Reviews.Title: Wonderful little thing, it is
Reviews.Author: Gatraz
Reviews.Content: My fiance got me a Fire to replace my broken Kindle Keyboard. I fell in love with the thing the minute I sat down and started exploring it. It's been my first foray into the tablet world, and I think that it's done everything pretty much right. The processing power does more than I need, the storage space holds all my apps and books I currently need, with some left over for music, and even the touch keyboard is a fair bit easier for me to manage than the Apple one. Yes, it's a little small, but since it's meant to be a modified eBook, that makes total sense. I even saved a small fortune by using a $0.97 pencil box as a carrying case, in opposition to the $50.00 things I see everywhere.I love the fire for its immediate access to my Amazon account, its great adaptation of Opera, and its superb reading environment; in short, it's worth five stars to me.

Reviews.Title: Poor planning!
Reviews.Author: Tiffany923
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Kindle with hopes of a reader for myself and access to educational apps and websites for my children...The main websites that we access (Starfall, ABCmouse, and Team Umizoomi) are all flash player supported....I purchased a Kindle Fire that was part of the "new" series that no longer supports Flash. However, they conveniently leave that information off of the advertisement/information page. I spent four hours searching for apps to support Flash, using Google to determine if this was possible, and speaking to customer representatives that didn't even know if the Kindle Fire would support flash and kept telling me to 'enable flash' when that isn't even a valid feature. I then called customer service to discuss my concerns and ask for a refund. They told me that I would have to return the item and within 2 weeks I should have a refund. Hmmm..they didn't wait until I received the Kindle to take the money from my bank account!!!

Reviews.Title: Disappointed compared to 1st Generation!
Reviews.Author: J. Wagner
Reviews.Content: I still love the over all concept of the Kindle Fire, but I am truly disappointed in the 2nd Generation.  I would have gladly paid the extra $40 (1st Gen $199, 2nd Gen $159) to get rid of the ads & to have a wall charger.  ARGH!  I purchased the second 2nd Gen to give as gift to a family member.  I wanted to pre-load all of the cool apps and essentials I've come to love about my Kindle Fire.  I'm seriously rethinking about whether I want to give someone a gift that is one constant AD!!!  YUCK!  How could Amazon screw up such a good thing?  Second disappointment, I can not get Overdrive Media Console to install on this Fire.  My first Fire I could check-out electronic books from my local library using Overdrive Media Console.  Please note I said "install", I know how to download the app, but I think the new operating system is blocking me from installing it. (Please comment if you can help!!!)  So, one of the reasons I was going to give this as a gift (library access) doesn't work. 2nd Gen = Total Bummer

Reviews.Title: Flash does work on the Fire and other tips
Reviews.Author: IslandGirl
Reviews.Content: Here are four things I've learned in the week I've owned my Fire.#1. The Fire will support flash, but you have to install Dolphin browser to run it.  That will use up part of the limited available storage, but it was worth it to me.  Go to the Kindle help forum and search for "adobe flash player is not on my new kindle." Read through the entire page and you will find a link to a "dropbox" containing the files needed to install flash player.  This is apparently an older version of flash which may not run everything you want, but it's better than nothing.#2. Buy the AC power adapter when you buy the Fire.  It will cost $10.00 more if you buy it separately later.  The Fire comes with a USB cord to charge the Fire via your PC, which is a much slower process.#3. Bookmark the following link: http://www.amazon.com/gp/help/customer/display.html/ref=hp_200127470_fire_2nd_gen_img?ie=UTF8&nodeId;=201009560.  You will need it.  This is the link to the Kindle user manual and helpful videos.  The information that comes loaded on the Fire is woefully lacking.#4. If the amount of storage is important, buy the Fire HD instead.I got my Fire on one of the pre-Black Friday sales last week.  For the price I paid, it is great.  I will have to say that if I had the extra money, I would have preferred the Fire HD with the extra storage capacity, camera, and HDMI port.  However, this one does what I really wanted a tablet to do and that's what matters.

Reviews.Title: Soooooooooooooo Disappointed, Want my old Kindle Back
Reviews.Author: Beefheart
Reviews.Content: I was in love with love with my Kindle Fire. My sweetheart had given it to me for Christmas and it was great!  So, when the 2nd generation came out, I could wait to upgrade.Boy, was that a mistake!The 2nd generation does have some improvements.  You can hook up to MS Exchange to get your work email without buying an App.  That's Nice. Also, it might be perceptibly faster.  However, in several important respects, it was actually WORSE for me than the first Generation.Ads, Ads Everywhere!I can't stand Ads.  On my new kindle, the wonderful photographic wallpaper is gone.  Instead, you are faced with a full-screen add whenever you wake up your Kindle.  These are especially irksome when they are for movies I Saw and hated.  I find myself unlocking the screen as quickly as possible just to get past the full-page ad.  Not the best way to set myself up for a quite hour of reading.Ads also sneak in in other ways.  When you pull up the shortcut for and app, the bottom of the screen is filled with obnoxious "suggestions for you". After paying $200 for this piece of "personal" electronics, I did not think I would it would be hardwired with so many ads that I do not want. Makes it seem less my piece of my `personal' electronics....  But that's not the worst. The Kindle Fire 2nd edition is definitely not equipped to read online news.I am a news junkie, especially for international news.  Probably my biggest Kindle use was browsing news websites from all over the world. I enjoyed doing from the couch at home and on the road.But, the new Fire DOES NOT SUPORT ADOBE FLASH nor can it be made to. So if I want the news video about Syria from Al Jazeera or the video of Greek riots on BBC, ... well..., I am just out of luck,  Instead I usually get a blank window with a puzzle piece icon.  This just reminds me of what I am now missing.Why Amazon would make this giant leap backward is beyond me.I really wish I had my old Kindle back.  I am now looking other brands of small tablets to switch to.

Reviews.Title: Woo
Reviews.Author: billcosby
Reviews.Content: I got a Kindle Fire as a cheap, quick, and easy replacement for my old Vizio tablet which broke about a month ago. I'm still new to the tablet/smart phone world, so I must say that I have pretty low needs and standards when it comes to these things. I am a grad student, and I need a device that allows me to check my email on the go, take notes, store books, and all that jazz. I don't play a lot of games and I don't use a lot of apps. That being said, the Kindle Fire has been suiting my needs pretty well.A lot of people complain about the ads. In particular, I've noticed a lot of people complaining that adult themed ads come up - this is true! Other than that, the ads are not all that annoying and they do not interfere with your use of the device. I kind of like the suggestion ads because they allow me to check out apps/books that I wouldn't otherwise go looking for.The battery life is OK - it's not stellar, but I can make it through a 3 hour class on a charge while taking notes and surfing the web. On Airplane mode, I can read and listen to music for about 5 hours. Contrary to other reviews, I have not had difficulty using the device while it is plugged in. It does not matter how you hold the device, the screen will always rotate smoothly and quickly.I am concerned about the small amount of memory especially because there is no way to upgrade. I have not filled up my 8 gigs yet, but I know that I can only carry a limited amount of music and that is kind of annoying.The Silk web browser is kind of slow and clumsy. At times, it is down right difficult to use.The touch screen is very responsive and the controls are fairly intuitive and easy to use. The speakers are pretty good, good enough to carry around with me while I do stuff around the house. However, there is no easy way to change the volume. You have to go into the device settings and do it that way - too complicated if you ask me.I like and hate how the opening page of the tablet is set up - all of your apps/books in a row with the most recently used ones coming up first. This make it easy to access the things you use all the time (like), but it also makes it nearly impossible to find items that you rarely use (Hate). I would prefer a grid set up, but I haven't figured out how to make that change.All in all the tablet has lived up to (but not exceeded) my expectations. It is quite obviously a device that Amazon created for amazonophiles so that they can quickly and easily consume materials and give them money. I have Amazon Prime (recommended!) and am in a stage in my life where I do heavily rely on Amazon for text books and other stuff so it works well for me. Plus, I am a poor student and the price was right.

Reviews.Title: Amazon Customer Service is AMAZING!
Reviews.Author: TLAkines
Reviews.Content: I loved my Kindle Fire the moment I got it BUT I noticed a dead pixel so I decided to contact Amazon. Within 3 minutes, via the "Contact Us" button and the "Chat" option, I had a replacement Kindle on the way. No sending mine back then getting a new one, no hassle, just apologies!! I am so glad I decided to get a Kindle instead of a Nook! Thanks Amazon for such amazing customer service!

Reviews.Title: I love my Kindle Fire, but I'm really disappointed by some of the features on it.
Reviews.Author: Sarah
Reviews.Content: Alright, I received my Kindle Fire last year for Christmas. As soon as I saw the box I was ecstatic because I'd been eying one forever but just didn't want to make the purchase. As I gleefully unwrapped it and turned it on I realized that I'd soon be using this for everything.And I have.I'm definitely a big electronics consumer, I have multiple smart phones, video game consoles, computers, mp3 players, cameras, etc. I work as tech support. I feel comfortable discussing the pros and cons of this tablet.So what are some of the best features in my opinion?-Ease of use. There's really not much of a learning curve. You literally turn it on, create/sign into your Amazon account, and from there it's ridiculously easy to find anything you need. Books? Got it. Movies, Apps, Games, Music? Got those too.-Portable. The perfect size. I don't feel ridiculous pulling this out if I take it somewhere with me to read. The screen is just big enough that I can comfortably let my eyes wander around it, and I can hold it with one hand. Also, I don't have swaddle it like a child and dread dropping it. It's sturdy!-The price is amazing for the amount of things that you can do on it.-I'm going to rehash the ease of use, because really, Amazon could not make it easier for me to get books and apps. I can spend 20 minutes just browsing through the free books they have to offer alone.-The processor on this thing can handle a lot of multi-tasking which is good if you're like me and get easily distracted by wanting to check email, testing out an app real quick, and then go back to reading while listening to streaming music.What are some things that I'm not crazy about?-The sound is terrible! Seriously, terrible! Maybe my Kindle just doesn't work correctly, but watching Netflix I need to be holed away in a room under the covers to hear maybe 50% of what's going on. Maybe my hearing isn't great. But this is my biggest gripe. With headphones in, I can't find the middle ground. It's either way too loud or way too soft. So frustrating.-Not enough customization. I like to tinker, and I'm also into design. And the look of the Kindle Fire just isn't clean, sharp and minimalistic enough for me. I want to be able to choose my fonts, icons, theme. None of those options are available on mine! I know, I know, the price is great. Why would I complain? Because it doesn't seem like adding these features is really that much more coding when you've got an Android OS backing it already.-Sometimes the Amazon app market takes forever to get applications your friends on other OS systems are raving about. Occasionally you'll get some sort of "generic" copy of it, but there's really nothing better you can do but wait for to finally reach the Amazon app market.-Lastly, having to purchase my own USB cable to hook it up to my computer was a bit of a pain. Could Amazon not have just made a USB/AC adapter?All in all, I definitely recommend it as a solid system, and a solid tablet. The price is remarkable for what you get. I just wish they'd fix the sound on mine. Maybe some sort of update? I don't know.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire 2
Reviews.Author: Steverd "s_denman"
Reviews.Content: Brought the Kindle Fire 2 for the ability to use for e-mail and reading books while traveling.  Just finished my first trip (overseas) and overall was satisfied with the ability to obtain by e-mail when WiFi was available.  However, I was disappointed with the battery life.  On our flight home,total time for flight and layovers was 7 hours.  Using the reader only, WiFi turned off, I was able to get only 5.5 hours of battery.  The unit had been charged for 8 hours before leaving.Would not recommend if you want to use the Kindle as I wanted.  In the future I will carry both the Kindle Fire and my old Kindle Reader.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire Review
Reviews.Author: Sue
Reviews.Content: I have enjoyed using the Kindle Fire, reading books, watched a movie, check email, facebook, play games.  What is really funny is that we created an 89 year old mom/grandma Kindle junkie paying games on it.  LOL!!

Reviews.Title: They didnt tell me they removed some features!
Reviews.Author: Father Time
Reviews.Content: I purchased a 2nd gen kindle fire after having the 1st gen kindle almost a year.  I liked all the new stuff they added, but they sure as heck didnt tell me about the stuff they removed from it.  Specifically the Adobe flash player.  My kids like this app called zoodles and it doesnt work without flash.  After trying to figure out how to turn it on, I called amazon tech support.  They said the new kindle currently doesnt support flash.  So I asked if it will one day, and they said they cant make any promises.  Sorry to say, this made me return the kindle.  I will likely get one again when it supports flash like the old kindle fire does(if I havent bought another competitors tablet by then)Also, if you are going to buy this tablet, pay the extra $40 for the 2 year warranty.  Your kindle WILL have problems in the first year.  There is about a 99% chance of that)  So if you dont want to buy a new kindle fire a year from now, spend another $40 for the warranty and make it last at least 2 years.  I went through 5 kindles fires in 10 months (usually battery issues where the device wouldnt charge, and one screen issue where it was green) In november my kindle fires limited warranty will be up, and I know I will be lucky if it lasts to the New year after that.

Reviews.Title: A top notch gift
Reviews.Author: Jolean Hitchen
Reviews.Content: I bought this Kindle Fire for my 65 year old husband that said he did not have any interest in any kind of a tablet and did not want to learn how to use one! On the day he opened the box he had it registered and was watching his first full length movie within 2 hours. He learned to check his e-mail and buy books on the second day. By day 3 he could download apps and play games. All of this was done without help or prompting! He loves his Kindle Fire, uses it every day.  I would buy this for anyone of any age, they will enjoy it immensely.

Reviews.Title: Could be a lot of fun... if you like reading next to your computer......
Reviews.Author: Anne Greene
Reviews.Content: Because the battery truly is nothing to shout about.  If you, like me, like to curl up in a big chair or in  your bed and read a good book on a rainy day, forget about that!  You will be reading next to your computer because this thing must be plugged in to your USB port to get juice.  Yes, you can charge it all day and yet it's only good for a couple of hours before it's turning off with no juice left.I thought one would be able to read a book with a charge, but even a short book, that's not going to happen unless you are a speed reader.  And games?  Forget about that too, because games just chew the battery up and you will be playing games next to your computer.What a shame this kindle doesn't come with a wall plug that charges the unit.  Sure you can buy one, but it might or it might not work on your kindle.  And if you buy it from Amazon, it's pricey to buy the plug that the usb cord plugs into. Why on earth doesn't it come with this plug?  What a pity.I will probably not buy another kindle until the price either comes WAY down or the battery gets a LOT better.  Or if it came with extra battery and a battery charger that isn't dependent on being inside the kindle to charge.... kind of like my digital camera, I can take the battery out and charge it and put a fresh one in while the other one is charging.Moving on.  The kindle is much heavier than I thought it would be.  It's hard to hold it up with your hands for any length of time.Also the kindle is hard to hold because the "frame" around the screen is so narrow.  I am constantly having to lay it down to "flip" back to the page I was reading because my thumb got too close to the screen and flipped the book back 4 or 5 pages or forward 4 or 5 pages.  This is irritating.On the good side, the kindle is easy to use and it's very easy to buy books for it.  It's also pretty easy to down load books.One thing I haven't figured out is how to get books that I've already read off the screen on the kindle.  They need to just stay in the cloud and not show on my kindle proper.  Of course, there's no manual to help with this and that is a shame.  I would think eventually I will run out of storage space on my kindle and then what do I do?  Buy another one and fill it up?  I'm sure there's a way to delete things, but darned if I can figure it out.All in all I love my kindle.  BUT I would suggest if you don't need one yet, I'd wait another generation before I bought.  I kind of wish I had.

Reviews.Title: NOT CHARGING two weeks after warranty runs out
Reviews.Author: K. Ayers "freshair"
Reviews.Content: This kindle stopped charging after the one year warranty expired less than two weeks ago.  Amazon won't honor the warranty like another company did for me, two months after the coffee maker stopped working.  I will be a customer for life with a company that values its customers.  Amazon obviously does not, since I order from them and least once or twice a week.  They removed my last review, we will see how long this one lasts.

Reviews.Title: disappointed as I thought I was "upgrading"
Reviews.Author: Karen Karelitz
Reviews.Content: I had a first generation kindle fire and exchanged it for the second generation kindle fire (non HD). I was originally thinking this would be considered an upgrade but I am disappointed. It freezes more often. It is overrun by ads. There are ads on the lock screen, suggested apps where the favorites used to be easily accessible, and an "offers" section at the top. They completely sold out to all these ads. They also no longer provide a wall charger but just a usb cord. I understand that I can charge it from the usb but I would rather have it near my bed. With the original kindle fire a wall charger was provided and not a usb. I was ok with that set up because the intentions of the kindle fire is that to use it and set it up there should not be a need to connect it to a computer. Everything can be managed right through the device or on amazon.com. I consider this an Amazon fail and miss my old device that I no longer have.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire--pros and cons versus the B&W; Kindles
Reviews.Author: Joanna Daneman
Reviews.Content: *Update: These Kindles go obsolete and this one is way obsolete now that the HD and HDX are available. Here are some thoughts for newbies to Kindles. If you previously had a Paperwhite or an e-Ink version, the Kindle Fire (HD or HDX) are not the same. They can't be read easily in bright light BUT they don't require a lighted cover or accessory light. They DO require an easel cover and you may end up reading them in landscape (sideways) rather than portrait. But some books are for portrait format only (this annoys me.) These Kindles are better at apps and games. You can watch downloaded video, so PRIME is excellent to add and it's worth having. Then, you figure out, the bigger Kindle is better for viewing but...it is larger for carrying. I like the smaller size because it's no bigger than a trade paperback and it fits in a purse. Finally, the Fires are an awesome travel tablet. I went all over the darn place (right to the end of the earth as it happens, South America and Patagonia.) Except for when we were cut off from civilization because they don't have a geosynchronous satellite over unihabited areas of the Atlantic or Pacific, the Kindle was a great device to grab email, yack on Facebook and check this and that. I even ordered a book and a few apps. The Kindle worked as my alarm clock and boredom-relieving device in airports, planes and long waits for various connections on a long journey. There is a multi-voltage kit for a fast charger and if you are a traveler to foreign places, I recommend it instead of the standard fast charger. Not much more, much more useful In short, this thing travels well. It doesn't hold a charge as long as a Paperwhite, so you have to strategize your charging. But I'm completely in love with my old Kindle Fire and am considering an upgrade.The Kindle Fire adds features not available on the older, black and white models. But it's a different creature and has pros and cons. If you want color, streaming video and many new books (especially cookbooks) you may find you must own a Fire to download those Kindle books--a new trend. Also, magazines work well on the Fire and are nearly useless on the black and white versions, no color, poor resolution of photos. So the Fire has its uses compared to the older Kindles, but it's not 100 percent perfect, either. The older Kindles have very good applications for which the Fire is not as optimal.  Here's my impression after a few weeks of use:1. Ease of reading: Flipping book pages is easy. You have a choice of formats, page curl, no page curl and a simplified text that fills the screen (more like the original Kindles.) To page through, you stroke the screen and the pages turn easily.2. Text size and picture size: to enlarge by stretching the screen, you move your fingers apart on the page. But if you are in the simple text mode, you cannot zoom in. I have heard from other users that it is harder to enlarge the text. In the b&w; Kindles, you can change the font size. You can also change some fonts in the books on the Fire, and you can employ text-to-voice mode. I didn't like the voice in the book I tried out--kind of a scratchy female voice, not something I wanted reading to me.3. Magazines: to look at pictures and zoom in, you need to be in normal mode, but for ease of reading, the simplified text makes the page fill the screen. I can't read some of the magazines in normal text mode; the print is too small. But one magazine was fairly good in this mode (a magazine on painting.) I enjoyed zooming in on the photos and they were brilliant. A cooking magazine (Vegetarian Times) was very readable. A knitting magazine was nearly useless--zooming in on the pattern chart left a lot of it out of the frame even turned landscape mode, and since knitting charts need to be big enough to read AND be visible from side to side, I decided I'd get my knitting magazine via CD/DVD rather than in a Kindle format. In short, not suitable for every magazine you may be reading.4. You need a constant WiFi to really take advantage of the Fire. I have no Wifi at work, so it's only useful for reading previously downloaded books. If I want to buy a new book, I have to find a hotspot.5. The battery runs down far faster--well, it's broadcasting to WiFi, it's projecting light through the screen, so it's power-hungry compared to the simpler Kindles. You will probably end up wanting the Power Charger, which works 3X as fast as a USB port.6. The screen gets smudgy from your fingers. Some screen protectors reduce the clarity of the text and picture resolution7.Yes, you cannot see the screen in full sunlight. Glare/screen protector needed, see comment above about reduced resolution.8. Cases are helpful--the glass screen is beautiful but subject to being banged around if you carry it in a purse or briefcase. So your purchase price is going to increase if you add charger, case and screen protector and maybe a stylus9. Hitting the stroke to activate the home icon can be annoying--if you don't tap just the right spot, can take a while (maybe a stylus would help?)Summary:This is great for reading magazines but not great for enlarging text in simplified text mode. It is heavier than a regular Kindle but you get color and streaming video. The speakers are adequate. If you want more tablet function for video, you'd probably be happier with the HD, for resolution, size and for the increased memory. Either way, if you buy a Kindle Fire, count on spending more, quite a bit more, to fit it out with case, stylus, screen protector and a faster charger that can be used instead of USB/computer charging.I still prefer my Kindle Keyboard for everyday use, but I like this because I can read magazines and see videos. I also prefer the Keyboard for travel--it's more compact, it stays charged for a longer time, and it has 3G, meaning I can download new reading material from nearly everywhere in the US, wifi or not. However, if you are a magazine and newspaper subscriber, and want tablet entertainment (apps, games and video) then the Fire is a good choice.

Reviews.Title: Love the Kindle Fire 7"
Reviews.Author: djames
Reviews.Content: I bought the Kindle Fire for my 5 year old son. I was going to get him a childs tablet for Christmas, but this was on sale for almost the same price.  I decided I would get him a real tablet with a better range of games, books and overall better quality.I bought the Kindle on Cyber Monday, and paid for 2 day shipping.  I bought it around 2PM, and received it the next day by 10AM.  I was incredibly impressed with how fast I received the product.Before getting the Kindle, I read a review that there wasn't a paper "Getting Started" guide in the packaging.  That review also went on to say that they had trouble navigating and figuring out how to use the Kindle.  When I received the Kindle, it didn't have the guide.  It only came with the Kindle and the USB cord.  Having a smart phone, I wasn't too concerned because I know the basic functions of a touch screen.  When you start the kindle, it walks you through a "Tips and Ticks" start up feature.  When you get to the main screen, there is a getting started guide in the carousel of "Apps" to choose from.  I applaud Amazon for being green!  That's a great place to put the guide, and you wont' have to worry about losing it! I, personally, found the Kindle very easy to navigate without using the guide.It does not come with a wall charger, but I used my iPhone charger and it works just fine 9 (and fast) in charging the Kindle.  If you plug the USB into a laptop, it charges VERY VERY slowly BUT if you drop down to the notification screen on the Kindle, it does proactively tell you that it's connected to a low power supply and it'll charge slowly.  It also tells you that while it's connected to the low power supply, it won't charge while the Kindle is in use.Overall, I found the set up process very easy and seamless. I was able to start downloading within minutes of setting up. The picture quality is simply amazing.  The video quality is crisp and the dual speakers are just awesome.  I brought up one of the free books pre-loaded on the device to test reading, and the quality is just as wonderful!  Very very easy to read the text.  The touch quality is just as great as the rest of the features, it's not slow or spastic.  I am extremely impressed with the quality of the product for such a low price.It really is a great little tablet, especially for kids.  I find it very user friendly, and I'm not concerned that my 5 year old wont know how to use it.  I love the Cloud part of this device.  It makes pictures/videos/music accessible without having to store it on your device (keeping memory free).  If you're thinking of getting your little one a tablet, I really encourage you to get the Kindle Fire 7" or Kindle Fire HD 7", because it's perfect.  Save your time, money and the headache of getting a child's tablet(having to connect it to the computer to remove and add things.. eck.).  You'll get more bang for your buck with the Kindle and you will not be disappointed!Or if you're thinking about getting this for yourself, I would definitely encourage it as well!  I love it!  I was having fun playing with it.Nicely done, Amazon.  As always, you've made me a very happy customer!

Reviews.Title: Super Nice Product
Reviews.Author: Mary J. Mcvey "mmbuddy"
Reviews.Content: I am a self-confessed gadget junkie. I bought the very first Kindle, the very first iPad, and have updated both now. I saw the promise of the future in the first Kindle. I loved the size and ease of carrying multiple books with me any time I wanted. Also, the battery life was great. (One thing I really miss on the new Paperwhite is the cool screen savers on the original Kindle.) Then I bought the iPad and used the Kindle app some, but there were way too many distractions on the iPad to read much. This year I decided to upgrade my ereader to the new Kindle Paperwhite. I have it and love it for reading.Now onto the Kindle Fire. When I ordered the Kindle Paperwhite, it wasn't supposed to be delivered until Dec. 21. I read reviews every day for the Paperwhite and started to get concerned about the negative reviews. I used the iPad in poor light or in the dark, but I wanted something smaller to take around with me. So, anyway, one day in early November I got a Lightning Deal on the Kindle Fire for $129.00. I decided what the heck. If I didn't like it, I figured I could give it to someone for Christmas or see about returning it. It ended up that I spent a total of $135.00 for the Kindle Fire and case and $158.00 for the Paperwhite and case. Still I got two cool gadgets for less than an iPad mini would have cost. I had considered the iPad mini at first, but I decided to wait for retina display on it before I felt compelled.I ended up getting the Kindle Fire and the Paperwhite on the same day. I tried both of them out, and I like both for different reasons. I decided to keep both even though I have two iPads already. The Paperwhite is as great as I thought it would be for JUST reading. It has nothing extra to distract me from the joy of the book.The Kindle Fire though was a surprise. I really like it too. I like the feature of it reading to you if you want. The Prime membership was a huge surprise too. I bought a new TV this summer and now I can watch a movie on the Kindle or my iPad on the Amazon video app and finish it up on the TV if I want. I am keeping the Prime membership for sure. I really think the Prime membership is necessary to get the full benefits of the Kindle Fire.Yes, the Amazon app store has a lot to be desired compared to iTune's app store, but the basics are there. For what I wanted it is great. It is smaller and easier to tote around and it does some fun things. If you want to save some money, the Kindle Fire is a good buy for a gadget that can actually do a lot and be an ereader too. I would recommend the Kindle Fire for every age.

Reviews.Title: First Kindle Experience
Reviews.Author: kilby123 "Jenn L."
Reviews.Content: I have recently purchased a Kindle Fire at our local Best Buy. I paid $ 159.00 for it, however by the time I purchased insurance, a screen protector, case, and the "Geek Squad" to apply my screen protector the final price was slightly over $ 300.00. I am new to tablets/ereaders and I have done some research prioring to purchasing. I am very happy with my Kindle. I have had it about two weeks now and I have quickly become accalamated with its functions. Please take it from me I am no "Tech Genius" and I completely figured this out in about an hour. I have read previous reviews about how terrible the "ads' were, but personally I have not been bothered by them. They only appear as I swipe across the main screen to unlock. Otherwise I have not encountered any undesirable ads or marketing. I would reccomend this to anyone who enjoys reading, movies, or music. The downloads are super quick and I have no problem accessing my wi-fi at home or when I take it to work with me. Great product....

Reviews.Title: *** Known charging problem *** Amazon does not offer support ***
Reviews.Author: Stanton A. Bailey "Nephidoc"
Reviews.Content: I had a Kindle Fire for about 2 years.  It starting acting up a couple of months ago.  My family has three kindles so I would just grab another while the Kindle was "Charging".  So the short story is the Kindle won't charge.  This is a common, known problem to Amazon.  Their support is to give you $100 off on your next Kindle purchase.Don't buy a Kindle.Just check out the user forums and see how many people are having this problem.  There are more reliable options out there.  I suggest you go with one of those.You have been warned.

Reviews.Title: I love the kindle fire!
Reviews.Author: Rachael
Reviews.Content: Coming from a teenager I love the kindle fire. In my humble opinion it's the best tablet. It's easy to use. You might not be able to do all the productivity things you can do on the iPad but if you're looking to have something to play with it's really nice.  The only down side is it doesn't come with a charger. You have to use the USB cable it comes with to plug it into your computer or use a USB charger you already have if you don't want to buy a new one.UPDATEI love my kindle even more now! I like to play games and surf the Internet but the kindle books are amazing. The display is clear and easy to see, no squinting. The X-ray feature is the cherry on top. It helps me keep track of things. The dictionary is also a nice feature. Being a high school student I will definitely buy all the books and textbooks I need from now on on my kindle. This is really a good tablet if you like to play games and go on the Internet and also a saving grace for students.

Reviews.Title: Went through 4 Kindles in 10 months...
Reviews.Author: M. Vallet
Reviews.Content: Would be a great product if it worked. There is a design flaw with the charger slot, which works it's way loose inside the unit and then it cannot make contact in order to charge. Had this happen 4 times...the last time was within two weeks of receiving the new device. Paid $199 for it originally, but was only refunded $159 when I finally gave up on it and asked for a refund. They charged me a restocking fee for a malfunctioning device? Really!? I would have upgraded to the newest Kindle Fire HD in the hopes that they fixed the problem in the new design, but not if I have to fork out $40 more $$ for it...and no guarantee that this won't happen again. As a longtime Amazon customer I was very disappointed.

Reviews.Title: On my 4th Kindle Fire... Thanks Amazon
Reviews.Author: T. You
Reviews.Content: I just got off customer support and they are sending me my 4th Kindle Fire.Yes.FOURTHThe first one, the battery flashed empty with a ? on it when it was plugged in and had no power unplugged.The 2nd one wouldn't show a loss of memory when an application was uninstalled so it filled up and I had no way, other than a hard reset, to get my memory back.The third one has a bad battery life, the battery only lasted an hour before it would die.I asked the customer service rep if I could just get a refund or a credit to buy an upgrade in hopes that the issues I am having are just a 1st generation issue. I was told I could get a $20 credit to put towards the purchase of the Kindle Fire HD but I was out past my 30 day refund period.That's ok, Amazon. I will just keep sending these back until I get one that workds.Here's to hoping #4 is a keeper.(and this is #4 in less than a year.)

Reviews.Title: can't use email
Reviews.Author: D. Reilly
Reviews.Content: Nothing but problems with hotmail and yahoo email. Called tech support and they get it working and then it doesn't. Can't reply to email, either no curser or no key pad pops up. If you're using it for this don't buy it.

Reviews.Title: Much faster, but not user friendly
Reviews.Author: 4MotherHen
Reviews.Content: I completely love the first generation Kindle Fire.  So as I pondered buying another for my kids to share, I was thrilled to hear that a second generation Fire was going to be released.  Both of my kiddos have significant developmental delays and had both responded very well to the first one.  So much so, I needed to buy another to alleviate the arguing.Well, I received the new one yesterday and am completely frustrated.  When you power the machine on, you can either unlock it with a swipe to the left, OR go to an ADVERTISEMENT with a swipe to the right. (Which you can unsubscribe to with a $15 fee) On the main home screen, there is the carousel and no longer are your favorites listed below....instead there are more ADVERTISEMENTS labeled "Customers Also Bought". I am so very sad that I can no longer let my kids use this Kindle without direct supervision to keep them from buying everything that looks shiny and exciting. (I do know I can turn off purchasing, but the device is back and forth so much that it would be a lot of hassle.)  It's highly annoying to me when I am using it alone.  It's far too distracting to even be usable with kids.  I don't even want it anymore.  I want another first generation Fire.  So disappointed.Definitely, it is a better product than the first generation, and I do understand that the ads help it be cheaper for us to buy.  It is unfortunate that this makes it unusable for my kids.

Reviews.Title: GOT IT RIGHT!
Reviews.Author: P. Steward "pls"
Reviews.Content: This is the one I have been waiting for!  I have a Galaxy Tab and had (and then resold)an iPad, so am familiar with tablets.  Tablets are not meant to replace computers for complex computing tasks and this device doesn't pretend to do so(although browsing, email and apps work well).The Kindle FIRE is easy to use and priced at a point that is accessible to most everyone.  Text-to-speech is the feature that is unique to the Amazon products and it is a mystery as to why Amazon isn't shouting this capability from the rooftops.  It enables a person to listen to the majority of the Kindle books on an infinite number of topics.  For even capable readers, this enables us to listen to a book when our visual attention is elsewhere (cooking, house chores, driving, computing), so it enables me to cover much more material than I would if I had to stop when other activities demanded it. TTS capability is only available on some of the Amazon products, so those for whom this is an important feature must carefully check the specs of the models they want before ordering.  It has now been enabled on the basic version of the FIRE (also on the DX, Touch and some models of the keyboard versions).The only thing that would make it even better is to make the TTS capability available on the new larger FIRE model.
